page.title: 12BIRDS
page.content: The area is rich in bird life-from the large handsome pheasant to goldfinch & wren.Wood pigeons & magpies are pests as is the once protected collared dove, near to houses. Woodlands provide food & nesting sites for many types of titmouse, thrush, blackbird, nuthatch, tree-creeper, yellow hammer, woodcock, dunnock, ,robin, chaffinch bullfinch & barn owls.Starling are everywhere in ever-increasing numbers. Larks, partridges & lapwings are to be seen & heard in the fields & in winter, flocks of redwing & fieldfares. The various stretches of water provide suitable habitat for swan, coot, moorhen, grebe, mallard, pintail duck & heron. There are visiting flocks of Canada geese which move from one pond or reservoir to another as do large numbers of herring gulls.
